segments.text: So you saw them coming and you were getting ready to attack?
Yeah, we were getting ready to attack.
And how many were you?
Was it just your tanks?
In my area of responsibility, they had ten German tanks and I think I had full strength.
I had fifteen or sixteen anyway.
The platoons were in pretty good shape.
They come out as if they were going to attack me.
And what they're doing, they're dragging those 10 tanks.
They drug four anti-tank guns behind them and put them in a position in which we couldn't see.
Dig them in in the sand and get them set up.
And then as they dropped off these, they're moving on toward us.
And we start exchanging fire.
And they withdraw.
And their tactics is for me to go charge it in there and get them, you know, as they pull out.
And they draw me right into these four anti-tank guns.
Well, I had, you know, you have to study the enemy or you're foolish if you don't.
So we had...
read about this, of them doing this against the British down in Eighth Army.
And I talked to my executive officer, the lieutenant of the captain.
I said, you know, I think we better be careful.
I said, I think we better send one platoon off around this flag here.
feel this situation out, and I said, we better stay here and overwatch them.
Okay.
Well, that's exactly what happened.
They hadn't moved a thousand meters until they started drawing fire from these anti-tank guns that these guys, jokers, had dropped off there and put nets over, sand-colored nets.
When they did that, we just poured the fire from the rest of our tanks right in on them and brought the artillery in on them and killed every damn one of them.
I never lost a tank.
Then we just moved out on through them and we engaged the Germans at that.
So then you started chasing the Germans after that?
Well, we started moving them and waiting for our other elements to move up and we went forward.
Most of them got away.
We knocked out a few.
I can't remember now, three or four of them, but most of them would get away.
You just don't go chase each other in the desert.
You just don't know what the hell.
You just can't afford to get yourself out on a goddamn limb as a part of the team.
And so the whole line of assault was moving.
Yeah, everybody moves.
What you do is you take intermediate objective.

You take your objective, and when you get orders to move your next objective, it means you don't move there until the commander decided that everybody's on his intermediate objective, and you just keep moving forward.
You have objectives to... Sure.
Every guy's got an objective.
If this guy's on his objective, it may enhance the movement of these others to get on the objective, but you don't let this guy go on to the next and next and next until everybody...
because this guy could end up getting himself cut off out there and screwing up the whole damn plan of action.
When did you next see some combat?
Then we saw combat on the way into... We were in and out of combat almost every day until the campaign was over.
In the Kass area?
Yeah, yeah.
And on into Brazardia and Tunisia.
And then from Sicily Wait a minute now.
Were the Germans basically doing defensive tactics?
Yeah, falling back.
Falling back slowly, just trying to hold you Falling back, and the damn Italians, they were giving up.
They were poor fighters.
They were a hell of a liability the Germans had.

They'd try to give up in the evening, you know, when they'd smell us out cooking some, brewing up some coffee or something outside the tank late in the evening, you know, heat up some meat or something, you know, canned meat or something.
They'd smell that.
They'd be laying away over there in the desert.
They'd come in under a white flag and want to give up.
And... Have some dinner.
They just wanted something to eat.
Hell, they don't fight.
They complained about the Germans...
They complained about the Germans wouldn't repair their vehicles in the workshop, and they didn't have vehicles that were in bad shape, and they couldn't fight very well.
Hell, they couldn't have fought very well if they'd had brand new vehicles.
God.
But anyway, they were a hell of a liability.
I asked a German lieutenant colonel we'd captured one time about
how well those Italians fought.
He said, well, from what I see, about like you're American Negro.
Well, I'll tell you what, he didn't know American Negro as well as I do, because I tell you, I had some hellacious fighters out of the American Negro, I'll tell you that.
How'd you get along with some of the captured Germans?
Did you ever talk to them?

Well, I almost went to jail over an Italian lieutenant general in Sicily who wanted to take all of his steamer trunks to the prison camp with him, and he refused to get him back in a two-and-a-half-ton truck with about 50 other Italians.
He complained, and Eisenhower, I guess, had it all investigated.
Anyway, nobody could ever find out who the guy was that asked the sergeant to put this guy on board and get him down to LSD and to hell with his damn steamer trunks.
They just never did find out too much about who in the hell that was.
Maybe they purposely didn't want to find out.
But I didn't have much to do.
As the war went on, I did a lot, I guess, for German soldiers that were wounded.
I tried to take care of every one of them as I would expect him to do my soldier.
Did you give them pretty good care then?
Oh, absolutely, absolutely.
As you know, the commanders carried morphine syrettes after a battle was over.
I remember one battle, November 16th, 17th, and 18th of November 1944.
One of my tanks had blown up a German assault gun.
The one soldier still alive had been blown out of the thing, and his leg was all gone, and he was bleeding to death except a piece of skin.
So I took a surgical kit that I carried with me, cut that leg off, put a tourniquet on it, cut that leg off, covered it with sulfanilamide powder.
That's about the only antibody we had.
Give him a shot of morphine.
bound that up, called my doctor, Swab, forward, Captain Swab, hello, great little surgeon, and he brought up a half-track, armored half-track, picked him up, and saved his life.
That's what I'd expect them to do for me.
And I think that they did, in every instance that they had the capability to do, but you've got to understand that
If you don't have capability, you can be accused of a lot of things.
A German soldier was having a hell of a time from 1944 onward for supplies and something to eat.
They were just having a hell of a time.
So sometime I guess our people didn't receive proper care because it wasn't there.
Now let's switch to Sicily.
Did your command change?
I was put in a position as a company maintenance officer for a maintenance company because of my background.
and was later promoted to major just after the Sicilian campaign.
I was responsible for the maintenance of the entire regiment.
I kept that through Sicily.
In other words, they took your command away then?
No, I was given another command, but one in which a major commanded instead of a captain.
Oh, I see.
The maintenance company had 12 tanks in it, in addition to all the maintenance capability for the whole regiment, 156 times three and the same number of half-track vehicles.
The Sicilian campaign lasted about a month.
I supported that operation.
Then we left every vehicle behind and went to England.
Got into England in November, Thanksgiving Day, in Burrock, Scotland.
And there we began to totally re-equip.
And now my maintenance experience, I can understand now what they were doing, what they had in mind.
I didn't know at the time.
But then Were you sad that you weren't going to be on an invasion of Italy?
They had decided that the Second Armored Division and the First Infantry Division were going to go to England, so we did.
The Second Armored and the First Infantry.
The only other division in my lifetime that I wanted to serve with in combat that I had great admiration and respect for other than the Second Armored Division was the First Infantry Division.
And would you believe, my first general officer, I had a general officer assignment when I was the first infantry brigade in Vietnam.
I was very happy about this whole thing throughout my 36 years.
So you went up to England in November of 43.
Yeah, I got there on Thanksgiving Day.
And we started receiving new equipment, later model equipment, totally.
It took every day we had until we took off and loaded up down at Portsmouth for the invasion.
Were you in on any of the planning or were you just basically maintenance?
Oh, I had all the planning for all the maintenance and logistic side of it.
before my regiment.
And then we went to, we were in Normandy, and I kept that maintenance company until October the 1st, 1944.
And then I become commander of the second battalion, the tank, the second battalion of the 67th Armored Regiment.
Tank battalion now, a whole battalion.
Now, tell me about Normandy.
When did you go on D-plus-1?
D-plus-1, yeah, D-plus-1.
And we were bombed severely and killed a Sergeant Major there.
And we fought the hedgerows.
You see, I had 12 tanks of my own.
And we got all, everybody got involved in the St. Louis breakthrough.

One of the reasons I guess I went to the 2nd Battalion when I took a battalion, when I got around to being eligible to be promoted to lieutenant colonel and they wanted to give me a battalion on the 1st of October of 1944 was I had many times taken my 12 tanks out of the
maintenance company as such and went with the 2nd Battalion.
So I knew them very well and worked with them very well.
As far as the battalion was concerned, what was your response?
About how many tanks were you responsible for?
I had 57 tanks, 3 assault guns.
That's a total of 60.
I had
then had a task force that usually gave me from one company to two companies of infantry.
And during the drive from the Rhine River to the Elbe River, I had a, remember now I'm a major,
still, about to be promoted to lieutenant colonel, but I'm a major.
I had attached to me a battalion of infantry, commanded by a lieutenant colonel, and a direct support battalion of artillery, 105 self-propelled artillery, commanded by a lieutenant colonel.
I had a tank destroyer company, and I had a reconnaissance troop
and I'm a major, and I command this whole entire task force with two lieutenant colonels under me in support.
How is that possible?
It's a matter of, I guess, of who can do what.
And rank has not anything to do with it when you really get the responsibility.
It's kind of like a brigadier general, you know, commanding a division.
Absolutely.
It just never happened in a peacetime.
Never happened.
But wartime, that's different.
Who can do what?
Exactly.
Who can do what?
That's what it's all about.
That's the reason why sometimes I've had, even in a Vietnam conflict, I've had a little private command in a rifle company.
because he had the radio and the company commander was down here somewhere and couldn't get to the damn radio.
And I said, son, you're in command as far as I'm concerned.
Now here's what we're going to do.
Well, a little private doing that.
Why not?
All you got to do is do what I tell him to do.
That's the way it goes.
That's the kind of little guy that, when he does a hell of a good job, as soon as you can, go land down there and pin a damn medal on him and help him send it back to his mama before he gets killed.
It's no fun presenting medals to mamas and papas posthumously.
Let him send it home while he's alive.
What was the first action that you saw after Normandy?
Then the daylights bombed out of us, I guess, by Luftwaffe.
They were very active.
We were supposed to have air superiority, but our air superiority was so high that they had air superiority.
We had the bombers, but they had the fighter bombers.
Yeah, that's right.
And they were ME-109s and FW-190s.
Oh, yeah.
And the one that hit us was a HE-111 with a 4,000-pound bomb.
And that was kind of a record.
It brought out the whole air ministry from England to look at the crater.
There were chunks.
It went so deep that there were chunks of clay, not square, but we'll just use, for example, 10 feet square.
That'd be about the size of this room here, I guess.
It came down and burst open a half-track, armored half-track vehicle.
That's how deep and how big it was.
The crater across the top was about...
40 meters I guess.
This was really a load and it must have been a delayed fuse that they had on it.
We saw him coming and he was very low level and of course we had 50 calibers to shoot at him but we never did hit anything.
We shot at one
ME-109 when we were on the, we just got in on the beach.
It was D plus one, early on D plus one.
And we began to spread out and get ourselves sorted out.
Here come a ME-109 and everybody started firing at him and they killed a Spitfire that was following him, that was chasing him.
So you see how bad things can get.
And this kind of upset the Brits, RAF.
But this HE-111 came in.
We were shooting at him.
It didn't make any difference.
He was very low, I'd say a thousand feet.
Boy, he hit right in the middle of the second battalion.
But everybody spread out and just tore up the battalion headquarters.
But then the St. Louis.
How many of these tanks were damaged on an attack like that?
Well, it busted up five of the half-track type armored vehicles in the headquarters and turned over two tanks.
Through Major Smith, the executive officer, about a hundred meters.
Did he survive?
Yes, sir, and let me tell you something.
He went to the hospital, and they let him come back in about a week, 10 days.
And I was a commander then of the battalion, and he was my executive.
Everybody, you know, people complained to me about him being irritable.
They said, Major Smith, he's kind of irritable.
He's always irritable.
Nothing suits him.
That's what some of the company commanders said to me.
I said, well, I'll talk to him.
And I said, I appreciate you telling me.
So I was sitting down with him one evening.
We had a hard day.
And I said, Smitty, how do you feel?
He said, well, I'll tell you.
He said, that German artillery today just tore me up.
Every round of that artillery just seemed like my head was breaking open.
I said, well, look, when did all this start?
He said, after we got bombed down on the beach.
I said, would you relent to going back to the hospital and getting this checked out again and then come right on back?
He said, well, it's getting to where it hurt me so bad, I think I'll
I think I'll, I don't want to leave.
I want to come back.
I said, okay, well, let's go get this checked out, and then you can come back.
Named Jerome Smith, one hell of a great guy.
And he went back, and they found a hairline crack in his skull.
He'd been living with this now for about six months, and I can imagine artillery tearing him up.
Gee whiz.
Isn't that something?
Hairline crack in his skull that they hadn't found before.
So he had to come back.
You just don't know how much pain a guy goes through at that sort of time.
But he didn't know, you know.
So he went on to come on back to the States.
But Normandy was a nightmare.
After the breakthrough,
Germans scattered all over the place.
They were trying to withdraw, and we were getting orders to move.
I get around to Brits.
Brits are wonderful guys and soldiers, but their high command is so methodical, and they take so much time, and they're so careful.
And you know, to the Brits, hell, what difference did it make to them whether the war lasted five years or fifteen years?
You just thought that the British were much too slow then.
That's much too slow.
So you agreed with what Patton had to say about Montgomery?
Absolutely, absolutely.
Take advantage of the breaks that you see on the battlefield and exploit them.
Besides that, what did you think of their soldiering?
Oh, I thought they were fantastic soldiers.
Oh, yes.
Fantastic system for training their officers and their men, but they just, God damn it, are slow as hell.
And they take their time about what they're doing.
They do a good job, but my God, they're slow.
Anyway, at Barrington, I was sent around behind at Barrington, France, to close off the Falaise Gap Park.
I never will forget, too, a couple of my tanks were occupying a roadblock where we had the Germans trapped.
in the fillet's pocket.
This was before we crossed the river and headed on up toward Belgium.
Here came two old armored cars up the road, and my guys were ready to, they had one German come down, and they let that German get down within 100 meters before they blew his motorcycle up
They blew a motorcycle up with a tank gun?
Yeah, they hit him with a 75 millimeter about 150 meters or something like that.
Well, I guess it was an hour or so, here came these two armored cars and they were about to get it when we had a radio set up on a
British radio that was supposed to tie up with it.
So these two tank crews were told that there was a possibility of British, so we let them come up and challenge them.
It was in the daytime, so they came up and we identified them as British.
You know, one of my sergeants, they were from, they were tanked from a vehicle from across the street there.
He said, hey, where you limeys been?
And he said, don't limey me, we're Canucks.
He's from Canada.
And then we pulled the hell out of there and got going and getting ready to go to, uh,
They got their break.
We got that broke through, and they had squeezed up a bunch of Germans in there, and so everybody started moving.
They went up to Belgium, Porte-Brasil, Antwerp, and we headed off toward Lige and Maastricht, Holland, and into Germany across the Siegfried Line.
Now tell me, what impact did the Battle of the Bulge have on you?
Yeah, well, I was a battalion commander then.
And first off, we had fought.
Were you a part of the Third Army then?
No, I was still in the Second Armored Division, but it took it away from Bradley and gave it to Montgomery, my part of it, up to North.
Now I'm under Montgomery.
So you were under Montgomery.
Yeah, I'm now under Montgomery.
I took it away from Bradley.

Preceding involves, by a month, we had jumped off on the 16th of November between the Siegfried Line, we were past the Siegfried Line, between the Worm and the Rohrer River, and we were fishing up that place called Lenik and Julik on the Rohrer River.
And Julek sports plots, which has been recorded in history as a great hangout, holdout for the Germans there.
We moved, I was commanding the battalion then, and we attacked on the 16th, 17th.
I finally took my objective on the 18th.
And as the 66th Regiment and the 67th Regiment
and I had the 2nd Battalion of the 67th Regiment, jumped off, pushed the Ruhr River at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 16th.
Two German tank regiments, we found out later, jumped off from their positions at 8 o'clock in the morning to push us back across the Ruhr River.

And that's probably one of history's meeting engagements where a light force is one going to attack the other force and the other force jumps off unknowingly to this and neither one of them know and they have a meeting engagement.
With approximately the equal number of tanks.
Equal number of tanks.
I think there's more than 500 in there.
And they had, it was mud, it was coal.
We had no air support.
We had tremendous artillery support.
Did the Germans have any air support left by them?
No.
They dropped their last bomb on me on
the 6th of October, as far as I know.
I never got bombed any after that.
And that was by a jet aircraft.
A jet?
A jet aircraft on the 6th of October, 1944, which turned out later to be a Me 262, one of the first jet aircraft in the world.
He dropped this bomb on a hedgerow over here, and I was on a trail here with a jeep, and it blew this air out.
This one, I guess, busted this one.
Didn't kill anybody and blew us out of the jeep, all three of us.
I was up at the head of a column of tanks moving.
I kind of used my, I had a Jeep with command radios in it.
I had a light tank with command radios in it.
I had a half track with command radios in it.
I had a medium tank with command radios in it.
And that represented my golf bag of tools.
Depending on what the situation was is what I got in.
What did you think when you saw it jump?
Well, I knew she was awful fast and you couldn't see any props.
And I said, man, this looked like another rocket.
But how can a rocket carry a bomb?
It was only about a 250-pound bomb.
How can a rocket carry a bomb?
That's what I thought.
Well, let's get back to your engagement now in December of 1944.
Two equal forces are heading toward each other.
Yeah, okay.
A guy named Batchelder, he had 56 tanks and a tank destroyer company had 12 tanks.
with 90-millimeter guns.
Our old tanks had 76-millimeter guns and 75-millimeter guns.
He had a destroyer company.
I had a tank destroyer company.
No, I did not have a tank destroyer company.
I had a platoon of four, 90-millimeter.
When we jumped off, they jumped off.
Harry Hilliard
He had the First Battalion.
We all started out with 56 tanks.
But Batcheller had a whole company of tank destroyers out of the 701st Tank Destroyer.
I believe he had, at least I know he had a platoon, because he had one tank destroyer that hit.
It was a diesel engine, something that I'd recommended for the whole Army back when I was testing them in the desert, that we have diesel engines.
It was hit 13 times before they were caught on fire.
Of course, there was nobody alive in it anyway, but it was shot up 13 times because the Germans determined they were going to set every one of our tanks on fire.
Batchelor ended up out of his 56th battalion with 19.
19 surviving tanks.
19 surviving tanks, and some of those had weapons busted on them, you know, a shell fragment that cut them up.
I had thirty-three left.
Healyard had twenty-one.
Now out of my thirty-three, most of the main gun would operate on, but some maybe the coaxial fifty caliber or thirty caliber wouldn't work on because of the shell fragments and the plus amount.
I was ordered then to go take the major main objective of their strength assault.
How did the Germans do?
Tell me in this.
Okay, Germans.
Was it a field or a forest?
No, it was a wide open mud terrain.
A few scattered little villages.
Low clouding, clanging clouds, foggish, muddy, cold, November type, northern Europe.
In the afternoon, it was a kind of a Spanish standoff.
In the afternoon, their two major regiments started withdrawing, and they deployed their 505th Heavy Panzer Battalion, which had 22 Tiger Royals.
Tiger Royals had the 88-millimeter gun, but my God, they had so much armor on them that instead of weighing them,
40 tons.
They weighed up to close to 60 tons.
So they were pretty slow.
Real slow and forklift-like guys.
But good maneuverability in the mud.
They deployed those.
One of my sergeants, if that had got into us, you see, our guns wouldn't penetrate their tanks.
We had to
The only way we'd penetrate their tanks really is to get up within 800 yards of them, 4 to 800 yards.
And with those 88-millimeter guns, they'd penetrate us out 1,000 yards, 1,200 yards.
So it made a hell of ahell of a
So what did you do, stay back?

Well, no, we just pounded the hell out of them and just keep fighting them and maneuver again and try to get on their flanks, you know, and hit them in the flank where they're soft instead of taking them head on.
It was hard to maneuver and they were maneuvering to beat hell in that mud with a big wide track and our tracks were much narrower.
But anyway, we just kept pouring in there and
One of my little sergeants, this is probably a historical mark, fired 32 battalion time on target of 105, 155, 8-inch gun, 8-inch howitzer.
An 8-inch howitzer round is 298 pounds.
A gun round, I believe, is a little heavier, about the same, I guess.
96 pounds on a 155 and a lesser amount on a 105.
But 32 battalions, 32 times 12 times 18 in some instances.
This would give you 32 times 12 is a good balance.
That number of guns were the rounds all hitting and exploding at the same time.
A little sergeant did that.
Brought all that artillery in.
Artillery in World War II was the best arm that we had in our army.
In Vietnam, it was the lousiest.
That's how we progressed with our artillery.
All rounds hit on those 22 tanks at the same time.
No kidding?
Every round burst at the same time.
This was so devastating.
to those tanks that they left three dead ones and they had two or three cripples and the rest of them withdrew.
That's what firepower will do for you.
Then it went on until So your artillery was behind you shooting over you Over me, absolutely.
I never got a chance to engage them.
It wouldn't have done any good anyway because they'd have knocked me out.
Soils.
It killed us.
Soils.
Day after day after day after day of the utilization of massive firepower.
And that's been a key to my whole tactical philosophy.
of used firepower, you make that by hand.
Don't use soldiers.
They're important.
They're made by God, grace of God.
So why use something important?
People are important.
Use some cheap materialistic thing.
So did you, as far as your tanks were concerned, did you try to hold them back then and just continue to maneuver while the Tigers were pounding at you?
No, what we did, this was late in the day,
Now the other two regiments that attacked us withdrew, and they were using this as their last gas, and they withdrew.
Why did they withdraw?
Because of the artillery?
No, because of our tank action.
We killed a lot of their tanks.
I see.
Because you could deal with it lighter.
Yeah, they're lighter.
They're Mark Fours and Mark Fives, yes.
It's getting dark, and we're consolidating our losses, getting casualties back.
We're refueling, re-ammoing, trying to get our stuff together, and still keeping the artillery on them.
And next morning again, we jump off during the night.
The assessment's made.
Hollingsworth, Task Force Hollingsworth, you go take Gernsweiler, their regimental objective, or the combat command B objective.
So I did.
How many tanks did you have left, 33?
So you took your 33 tanks?
Yep, and went on and took the objective.
And what was defending the objective?
Not too much.
A few German tanks, most of them had withdrawn.
but the most devastating artillery that I had received during the war.
So the Germans were waiting for you then?
The Germans were waiting for us, and they occupied the high ground on the other side of the Ruhr River.
They had the observation on me, and I had to go take that objective anyway.
How many casualties did you take?
I had four more, about five more tanks hit from enemy artillery.
Before you could wipe out their artillery?
Yeah, before we could get our artillery in range to hit them.
I don't know how many people I had dead and wounded.
I had a lot of wounded, but not so many dead.
And I had, while we were, I had an assault gun.
That was a 105 short barrel gun on a M4 tank chassis.
I had three of those in the platoon to fire indirect.
They could fire direct, but they made to fire indirect.
They represented just a half of a battery of artillery in that part.
The artillery was so bad, the enemy artillery was so bad, they were hitting, destroying everything.
One round hit right next to my headquarters, which is in this little old village of Gernsweiler.
We tried to remote our radio down into the basements, you know,
To save the soldiers, we'd just leave a radio outside in the armored vehicles with the sandbags and that sort of stuff around the tank.
We'd just remote those down in there and operate from down in there.
Infantry and the tanks married up out to defend the Gernsweiler.
And a round came in, a very heavy round, a 150 caliber bore.
And it hit on the deck of one of those assault guns, and the little guys were down inside.
And I knew that round had hit very close, so I get outside, and sure enough, in the midst of this heavy concentration, it hit this tank.
I got up on the back end of that tank.
They had clothing, and they had camouflage nets and that sort of stuff, and that stuff was all on fire.
And I kicked this fire off.

in that artillery and got down in the tank and the little guys was all right and I said you can either stay out here or you can come with me down in this basement because there's no way you can fire out here accurately and do any good with this incoming artillery like it is.
They said sir we'll stay in here

don't you want to stay with us I said no I said I've got this fire out out here now you're going to be all right and I'll go back I said I got to get back and get on that command radio so I do in about a month's time I get called up to the
and things was quieted down, I guess, in not quite a month's time.
We pulled into a place called Oad Wilder to get refitted and get ourselves sorted out and we were gonna have Thanksgiving dinner down there, whatever it was.
Christmas dinner?
No, Thanksgiving, because this battle was over and then on the 18th or 19th we got pulled out and we went into a little old town just south of there named Oad Wilder
Eighteenth or nineteenth of November.
Yeah.
So, we were going to get new equipment on the floor.
That had to come up from the bases down south.
